1.name: Title 1
1.text: Friction is the Enemy: Why Centralized Delivery Feels Slow

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 2
1.text: Section heading (top): Centralized IT Delivery (Budgeted, Staffed, Planned in Batches)

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 4
1.text: Top flow step 3: Capacity staffed (FY+2 mo)

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 6
1.text: Top flow step 7: PI planning / scheduling

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 7
1.text: Top flow step 8: Build → QA → release

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 12
1.text: Top net callout: Net: 9–12 months to usable value. Misalignment drives rework.

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 13
1.text: Section heading (bottom): Embedded Pod + Hub Guardrails (Continuous Delivery)

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 14
1.text: Bottom flow step 1: Capacity funded to the business

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 15
1.text: Bottom flow step 2: Kanban: build in small increments

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 16
1.text: Bottom flow step 3: Automated guardrails (tests, policy-as-code)

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 17
1.text: Bottom flow step 4: Direct feedback loop

1.name: Rounded Rectangle 18
1.text: Bottom net callout: Net: weeks to value. Less translation. Faster learning.

2.name: TextBox 3
2.text:
The Freight Train (Scaled Agile)
Best For: ERP & Back-Office Stability.
Why: Efficient when the destination is known and the route is stable. Optimized for batching and predictability.
The Convoy (Fusion/Pods)
Best For: Innovation & External Products.
Why: Necessary when terrain is uncertain. Small, autonomous units that can re-route instantly based on feedback.

4.name: TextBox 4
4.text:
The Tooling Mix: Provide seamless access to best-in-class tools (BigQuery, Databricks, Cloud Run) without bureaucratic friction.
Automated Governance: Quality checks are baked into the pipeline (Protect, Measure, Enforce), replacing manual review gates.
Golden Paths: Pre-secured templates for BTs and Fusion Teams to start building immediately.
"Make the Right Way, the Easy Way."

5.name: Rounded Rectangle 2
5.text: Divider line (thin): spans across under title

5.name: Rounded Rectangle 3
5.text:
Card (Left): The Business Technologist
Role: Domain Expert (e.g., Supply Chain Analyst) using AI agents and low-code tools.

Focus: Rapid prototyping of local business logic. “Vibe coding” allows them to build 80% of the solution instantly.

5.name: Rounded Rectangle 4
5.text:
Card (Right): The Analytics Team
Composition: Small squad of Business Technologists + Analytics Lead.

The “Analytics Lead”: The Semantic Modeler. Unlike Data Engineers who move raw data, the AE uses tools like Dataform to create data modeling pipelines that build the core data models used for analysis & ML.

6.name: Rounded Rectangle 4
6.text: Left card header: icon (group/people) + "The Fusion Team"

6.name: Rounded Rectangle 5
6.text: Right card header: icon (helmet) + "Forward Deployed Team"

6.name: Rounded Rectangle 6
6.text:
Left card body text:
Where: Internal IT / Product.

Model: Lightweight, cross-functional squads (4-5 utility players). Faster than SAFe, less dense than a Forward Deployed Team.

Use Case: Building scalable, multi-tenant Enterprise SaaS products.

6.name: Rounded Rectangle 7
6.text:
Right card body text:
Where: Embedded with Client / Complex Business Area.

Model: Elite, high-talent density. The "Special Ops" approach.

Use Case: Only for high-ROI, "messy" problems where being on-site is the only solution. Solutions are "extracted" back to the platform.

7.name: Rounded Rectangle 4
7.text: Right diagram outer panel (rounded rectangle, very dark, subtle border)

7.name: Rounded Rectangle 6
7.text:
Body text: Establishing a professional home for technologists who sit outside of
traditional Engineering but drive technical value.

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 16
10.text:
CHARLOTTE CURRENT EXPERIENCE
Charlotte’s current experience
• Diluted priorities (Charlotte is 1 voice among many)
• Slow feedback loops (requirements → build → learn)
• Unclear accountability (who owns my outcomes?)
• Low visibility / low control (doesn’t feel like "my team")

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 17
10.text:
WHY CHARLOTTE IS HAPPIER
Why Charlotte is happier
• Control: priorities flow through Erika (in her org)
• Clarity: obvious accountability (Erika + pod)
• Cadence: fast demos and course-correction
• Visibility: dedicated team working her outcomes

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 18
10.text:
TODAY STEP 5
5. Outputs delivered to CoC

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 19
10.text:
FUTURE STEP 5
5. Outcome metrics
improve for CoC

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 20
10.text:
BOTTOM LEFT BOX
What stays with Chad / centralized IT
• Shared CoC platform needs and cross-unit initiatives
• Multi-BU work requiring broader dependency coordination
• Central standards / governance enforced via Hub enablement

10.name: Rounded Rectangle 21
10.text:
BOTTOM RIGHT BOX
Transition (how we move from Today → Future)
1. Carve out Charlotte-specific initiatives from the centralized queue
2. Name Erika as Product Owner + establish decision cadence (weekly priorities)
3. Allocate Charlotte-funded Fusion Team capacity (BT + engineers)
4. Run a 60–90 day pilot with demos + outcome review; scale if successful

11.name: Title 1
11.text: Role Evolution: From BA/TPM to Business Technologist + Flow Leadership

11.name: Rounded Rectangle 8

EVOLVES TO →

11.name: Rounded Rectangle 12

11.name: Rounded Rectangle 15

11.name: Rounded Rectangle 18
11.text: FOOTER SUBLINE: Business owns outcomes & funding · Pods own delivery · Engineering owns standards & quality

12.text: We remove the layer—not the functions

12.name: Rounded Rectangle 20

12.name: Rounded Rectangle 22

12.name: Rounded Rectangle 23

12.name: Rounded Rectangle 26

13.name: Title 1
13.text: Rules of the Road: Decision Rights in the Matrix

13.name: Rounded Rectangle 2
13.text: The Business decides where we go. Engineering ensures the car is safe and fast. The Business Technologist drives.

13.name: Rounded Rectangle 9
13.text:
OWNER
Decides problem selection
& value targets.

13.name: Rounded Rectangle 16
13.text:
APPROVER
Vetoes only if security
standards violated.

13.name: Rounded Rectangle 17
13.text:
Product Lead
(Balances user need
vs. constraints)

13.name: Rounded Rectangle 27
13.text:
Vertical Lead
(Talent bar is protected
by function).

Eng/Hub Standards

secure defaults · automated checks

Business Technologist Vertical
(Professional Home + Talent Pool)
Hiring bar · Coaching · Leveling · Standards

14.name: Rounded Rectangle 10
14.text:

Hardline for craft. Embedded for outcomes.

14.name: Rounded Rectangle 11
14.text:
No ticket intake
BU-funded capacity is protected

15.name: TextBox 3
15.text:
The Business-First Builder: AI enables the domain expert to move from "requirements writer" to "solution prototyper."
Vibe Coding: Focusing on business intent ("Show me rebate leakage") rather than syntax. The AI handles the boilerplate.
Functional Wireframes: Using AI to instantly visualize user flows and data logic, iterating in real-time with stakeholders.

16.name: TextBox 3
16.text:
The Force Multiplier: Engineers shift from writing syntax to orchestrating multiple AI agents to generate volume.
Scale: A small team of 4 can achieve the output of 10 by leveraging agents for documentation, testing, and boilerplate.
Automated Quality: The "Quality Engineer" role evolves to building the "Test-Feed-Fix-Verify" loop—automating the rejection of insecure AI code.

17.name: Rounded Rectangle 2
17.text: Card 1: Mandate the Platform Team to build “Golden Paths” for AI (Secure Sandboxes) and Data.

17.name: Rounded Rectangle 3
17.text: Card 2: Establish the “Business Technologist” organization, career ladder, and governance standards.

17.name: Rounded Rectangle 4
17.text: Card 3: Deploy Fusion Teams into BUs (merging IT & Business) and launch an FDE pilot for a major client.

17.name: Rounded Rectangle 5
17.text: Card 4: Reinforce values: “Soft Lanes,” “Failure is OK,” and “The Players Matter” to empower the new verticals.
